data.title: Mad science at the Questacon circus | PHOTOS
data.meta_description: HOLDING fire in your hands, lying on a bed of nails and levitating beach balls might sound like...
data.text:
HOLDING fire in your hands, lying on a bed of nails and levitating beach balls might sound like the stuff of magic.

But, as the Shell Questacon Science Circus showed, itâ€™s actually the stuff of science.

As the circus rolled into town, the budding science enthusiasts rolled up, with hundreds of children across the region flocking to TRECC this weekend to experiment with a little fun.

Presenters from the Australian National University enthralled onlookers, and there were more than 40 interactive stations to explore, taking science out of the lab and into the hands of local kids.

The circus came at the end of a week where the group entertained local school students with flying rockets, freezing cold liquid nitrogen and gooey slime.

The science circus is celebrating its 30th year of inspiring communities to engage with science and technology and discover more about the world around them.
